text:
Most restaurants refuse to deliver to this part of City Z. At the delivery company you work for, you’re the only one that’s willing to come to this area. Sure, your company charges a bit more for you to come here, but that’s not what you like about the job.

More than the money, you like how quiet and desolate it is here. The only other humans you see on the streets are right near the barrier that separates this area from the rest of the city. Bold teenagers, the occasional stupid drunk that’s there on a dare, influencers trying to get an edgy picture to post. They always give you weird looks when you ride by on your bike.

You don’t see any of them today, which makes you slow down just a bit. Digging in your pocket, you pull out your phone to check for monster sightings. Not that a monster sighting would stop you from continuing into the ghost town! No, you’ve pedaled past them on the sidewalk before and even had to break out the stun gun a couple of times. You’re not a chicken; you won’t let a monster get between you and your paycheck.

Seriously, you need the money. If you’re ever going to get your own place. You’ve been living with your friend and her boyfriend for a while, but that’s…awkward. Feeling like a third wheel, even when you’re just trying to enjoy your time off at home. Getting your own apartment would feel a lot better.

There haven’t been any monster sightings in the area. You raise an eyebrow and look forward, down the road. It’s pretty quiet right now. Not eerily quiet, though. So you start pedaling forward again.

It shouldn’t take too long to finish your delivery and it’s the last one for the day. Really, all you have to do is put it down in front of their door, snap a picture on your phone for proof, and then you can head home. It’s never that quick and easy with these two, though.

All around you, the only sound you can pick up is the wind and the shifting of dirt on the pavement. There are no birds, no stray cats or dogs, not even rats. Honestly, it’s pretty surreal. The place looks like it should be full of people, but it’s so empty.

It’s not as empty as you think it is. You think you’re alone, riding your bike down the street, but you’re not. Someone is watching you from the shadows. Staying out of sight, but keeping his eyes focused on you.

Speed o’ Sound Sonic has seen you in the area before. You come here at least twice a week, sometimes more. Always alone, on your bike, with food. Always staying for a few hours before you leave again with a smile on your face. It all points to only one conclusion: you’re friends with Saitama.

Why else would you visit so often? And why else would you look so happy? So either you’re his friend or you’re dating him. Either way, you’re close with the bald hero and Sonic can use that to his advantage.

A grin begins to draw at the corners of his lips and he lifts a hand to cover it. He can’t help it, though. So excited to have found Saitama’s weakness, so eager to move forward with his plan. It’s a little devious and he knows it, but if his plan works then he’ll finally be able to beat him.

Sonic moves from one spot to the next, always keeping you in his line of sight. He’s been watching for a while, but he still isn’t sure who you are exactly. You have to be a hero or something, right? Probably one of the lower classes and lower ranks, since he’s never seen you on the news.

You’re not very flashy, for a hero. Always showing up in what looks like your street clothes. You don’t seem to have any gimmicks or special weapons. Just that stun gun that he’s seen you use on a monster once. Dodging monsters on your bike seems to be your specialty.

The fact that you prefer to dodge the monsters instead of taking them down like most heroes would proves that you’re there for Saitama. Not to train. Not to defeat monsters, like some of the overly confident heroes that come wandering into the ghost town thinking they’ll be able to clear it out alone.

Sonic watches you pedal down the street, but he has your route memorized by now. He knows that you like to slow down when you get close to the shopping district because you like to look at all of the stores that have closed. He knows that you like to take pictures of the desolate streets and abandoned restaurants. It’s actually a kind of cute, how you take pleasure in weird things like that.

You have no idea that you’re being watched, that you’ve been watched for over a month. Completely oblivious, you’re just thinking about what you’ll have for dinner tonight. Wondering if your roommates will want to get takeout or if they’ve gone off on a date night. It’d be kind of nice to have the kitchen to yourself for once.

The apartment building comes into view and you dismount to walk with your bike the rest of the way. There’s no reason to lock it since there’s no one else around so you just leave it propped against the building like always and begin climbing the stairs to get to their floor. Level after level, passing floors of vacant apartments. The only sounds are your footsteps on the stairs and the wind.

When you knock on their door and hear the call of “just a minute”, you’re more than happy to wait. If it wasn’t your last delivery of the day, you might be a little less patient. Every time you bring them food, it’s never quick. You usually end up spending at least an hour hanging out with them and sometimes that takes a toll on your paycheck.

The door opens and you expect to see Saitama, since he’s the one that called to you. Instead, you find Genos. You can tell by the apron he’s wearing that you’ve interrupted something so you bow and apologize for the intrusion. Between the two of them, you’re way more concerned about pissing off Genos.

“Sensei has been waiting for you.” The blond cyborg opens the door wider to let you in and takes the bag of takeout from your hand. “Everything is here this time? The last time we ordered, the restaurant forgot-”

 “Extra condiments.” You pull a few packets out of your pocket and hold them up for him to see. A half-smile curves your lips as his metal fingers take them from you. “I told them about it last time, but they said they couldn’t do a refund since there’s no extra charge for these.”

“The menu says that the order comes with two packets.” Genos is trying to argue with you as you walk further into the apartment, trailing behind you and checking the boxes in the bag to make sure everything is there.

Does he want to be refunded for like fifty yen worth of condiments? Honestly…you bought these “extra packets” yourself because you know Genos won’t let this go. You thought that maybe if he thought these came from the restaurant, maybe he’d drop the subject. You should’ve known better.

You step into the main room and find Saitama in front of his tv, plugging a second controller into the game system that’s set up. “Hey,” you greet him, smiling when he looks at you over his shoulder.

“Oh. Hey. You got here just in time. Sit down.” He shuffles back to sit on the floor next to you, pushing the controller into your hands and taking up the other one. “King left this here for me to practice and I need someone that won’t let me win every time.”

A glance toward Genos shows him looking over at you both before carrying the bag of takeout into the kitchen. No hint of guilt on his artificial face. You know him well enough to know he doesn’t feel sorry about it. Everything he does, he does for the sake of Saitama; even if it’s something he just thinks is in the older hero’s best interest.

“Have you played this one before?” Saitama drags your attention back to the game. His deadpan stare is directed at the screen, fingers already poised near the buttons and joystick on the controller.

“Not yet.” It looks like…another fighting game. Except that this one has characters that are all very cutesy.

“Did you see any monsters on your way in?” He pauses to scratch at his stomach through his shirt. Saitama doesn’t sound worried, doesn’t frown.

“Not today. It’s pretty quiet out there right now.” The game starts and you launch into it immediately, but you keep talking. “I can’t stay for long today. I want to try to get out of the ghost town before sunset.”

“What? Isn’t that just an hour away? Come on. Genos can take you home if you stay later.” In his reflection on the screen, Saitama’s eyes briefly flick in your direction.

Gritting your teeth, you manage to land a combo and KO his character. “I don’t want to impose. I mean, I know Genos-san has stuff to do.” You wait for his character to get up for the next round and continue. “I should be fine, I guess. I have my stun gun.”

A stun gun can only really help you if the monster is a lower level threat. Like a wolf level threat. Even then, monsters sometimes travel in groups. If you got attacked by a group of them, you’d pretty much be screwed. The stun gun really isn’t the best weapon against monsters, but it’s all you’ve got.

You’re not a hero; you’re a delivery girl. The fact that you go into the ghost town is already going above and beyond, but fighting off monsters? That’s high above your paygrade. Sure, you could ask a hero for help. Plenty of Class C heroes would probably escort you if you ask, but you don’t want to bother them.

How ridiculous would that be? Calling for a hero every time you have to make a delivery. You shake your head, thinking about it as you leave the apartment. It’s already much darker than it was when you went inside.

On the horizon, the sun is dipping low and casting a warm orange glow across the sky. The shadows are growing and it makes you uneasy. You hurry down the stairs and to your bike, listening for movement and only hearing the wind. This seems like a good time for monsters to start emerging so you need to be quick.

Climbing onto your bike, you begin pedaling off down the road. Not casting a glance back at the building, not bothering to look around. Your legs pump harder, carrying your bike faster and trying to focus on just getting out of the ghost zone. The sooner you’re out, the safer you’ll feel.

Sonic has been waiting for you to leave Saitama’s place. His eyes narrow on your figure as you stand up and pedal faster, like you’re trying to outrun something. Oh…did you finally notice him?

Covering his mouth, he tries to hide the grin that’s taking form. You’re more perceptive than he thought, aren’t you? How could he underestimate you like that? There are no monsters behind you so you can only be trying to run from him!

It’s cute, laughable, for you to think you can escape. Who do you think you’re up against? Sonic leaves his perch on a roof near Saitama’s and begins moving among the shadows. Approaching you rapidly and waiting for you to look over your shoulder at him, his heart pounding with anticipation.

You don’t look back. No, you just keep moving and staring straight ahead. He doesn’t understand why you haven’t glanced over your shoulder, but it doesn’t matter. If you won’t face him and fight him with honor, Sonic will just have to take you without any fight at all.

The wind is rushing past your face and you’ve built up a pretty decent amount of speed. You follow your usual route, the quickest route, back toward the edge of the ghost town. Just as you’re thinking that it won’t be much farther, you feel an impact against your bike and everything happens so quickly.

In the blink of an eye, your body is flying over the handlebars and you skid over the pavement. The air is forced from your lungs and you’re covered in scrapes. Your hoodie and jeans are ripped in some spots. Blood runs down the side of your face and dots your palms as you struggle to push yourself back up.

Looking back at your bike, your eyes widen at the sight of what looks like a shuriken buried in your now flat back tire. You lift your gaze, trying to find the source of the attack, but you don’t see anyone. Then you feel fingers tangling in your hair and yanking your head back.

Large grey eyes are staring down at you with disappointment. The man holding your hair sighs and he crouches down to your level. “I expected more from someone like you. You made this way too easy for me.”

This…isn’t a monster. No, this is just a guy. A guy with black hair that’s tied back in a topknot with a few stray strands hanging over his eyes. There are strange purple markings underneath his eyes, like makeup or tattoos, and he’s wearing a black tracksuit as if he’s been working out in the ghost town.

You can feel blood dripping off your jaw onto the cement. What is this guy doing in the ghost town? This is a guy…right? He does kind of have feminine hips. You try to push that thought to the side because it’s ridiculous and there’s warmth blooming in your cheeks.

Are you blushing? Sonic leans closer, a grin tugging at his lips. He’s trying so hard not to let his bad habit show, but it almost feels like you’re teasing him. Is this your twisted way of flirting? Pretending to be weak so he’ll make the first move and now, at any second, you’ll show him how strong you really are?

He’s thinking about what to do next. If he lets go of you, you’ll either attack him or try to run again. Either one could be interesting. You’re close with Saitama so you’re bound to be strong like his student. Maybe that’s why you don’t usually fight monsters; you just don’t see them as worth your time.

Sonic should’ve known better than to let his guard down. While he was contemplating his next move, he didn’t notice you making a move of your own. He didn’t see your hand slip into your pocket for the stun gun so when you shove it against him, it takes him by surprise. A strong jolt of electricity races through him and makes him tense for a few seconds before he manages to shove you aside.

You try to push yourself to stand, but before you can even get onto your elbows, the sole of his sneaker presses down on your wrist. He grins down at you, lightly grinding his shoe against your wrist and making you wince at the pain. Your fingers finally fall open, releasing the stun gun and letting it fall onto the cement to the side.

“My wallet…it’s in my back pocket,” you tell him, hopeful that he’ll take it and leave. To your dismay, he doesn’t do that. One blink and he’s straddling your waist, leaning forward with his face above yours and his fingers tangled in your hair again.

“We don’t have much time. I need to take you before Saitama shows up. But don’t worry, Y/N. We can pick up where we left off later.” It’s the last thing he says before he lifts your head and smacks it harshly against the cement, knocking you out.

You should just give Genos fifty yen from your wallet. That’s the first thought that comes to mind when you start to wake up. It might be the hit to the head or the impact from flying over the handlebars of your bike, but for some reason it feels really important that you give Genos fifty yen.

Opening your eyes, you stare down at your lap with that stupid thought bouncing around in your head. You know Genos doesn’t forgive dumb little slights like forgetting sauce packets. One time when you borrowed their bathroom, you forgot to put the seat up again when you were done and he never let you forget about it. Just give him the fifty yen and tell him the restaurant sent it as a refund.

“Ngh.” You wince as you wake up a little more, becoming aware of the throbbing pain at the back of your head. When you try to put a hand to the area, you realize your hands are tied behind your back. Eyes widening, you slowly lift your head and remember what happened before you blacked out.

The bike accident, the shuriken buried in the back tire, that guy that grabbed you. It’s now that you notice the warmth against the side of your arm and shoulder, a slight pressure. You hear the rustle of paper and your pulse quickens as you look at him from the corner of your eye.

He’s sitting beside you on the floor, close enough that your shoulders are touching. The menus from the saddlebag on your bike are spread out in front of him and he’s looking through one right now. Large grey eyes skimming the list of dishes, lips set in a straight line like he’s giving it a lot of consideration. The black tracksuit from earlier has been replaced by a pair of tight black pants and a shirt that’s hanging off one shoulder to reveal the strap of his tank top underneath it.

“Where…am I?” It’s asked with hesitation. You don’t know his intentions.

Honestly, you kind of thought he might be a member of the yakuza when you saw him in that tracksuit earlier. Before he knocked you out, you thought he might just be after your wallet; it’s not uncommon for delivery people to get attacked because people think they’re carrying a bunch of cash. The fact that he knocked you out and brought you to a second location tells you he wasn’t after your wallet.

His head turns and he raises an eyebrow when he sees that you’re awake. “I didn’t think you would wake up so soon,” he comments, shifting his gaze back to the menu in his hands. “You’re at my base.”

A look around makes you kind of…question this. It looks kind of meager for the base of some kind of criminal. The only indication that he might be someone dangerous are the weapons sitting against the far wall, but you’re pretty confident that this guy is working alone. You’re still not sure what his intentions are, though.

Feeling around behind you, you don’t feel your phone or wallet in your back pocket. You know your stun gun isn’t on you anymore. He probably took it for himself or left it on the street. Same with your bike, which really sucks because that thing wasn’t cheap!

Subtly tugging at the rope around your wrists, you try to keep him distracted. “Who are you and why did you bring me here?” Honestly, you’re not expecting him to explain himself. Why would a kidnapper tell their captive-?

“My name is Speed o’ Sound Sonic. And I’m holding you hostage so Saitama will fight me.” He offers the information so easily that it leaves you a bit taken back. The man beside you is smirking as he finally turns to face you, his shoulder drawing away from yours. “It took a while for me to discover his weakness, but now that I know it, I have an advantage.”

“Saitama-san’s…weakness?” You can’t help tilting your head as your wrists go still behind your back. For some reason, you can’t keep your eyes on him. The sight of his smirk makes you feel flustered and warmth rises to your face when he leans closer, a hand resting on the top of your head.

“You’re his weakness,” he replies with confidence. Sonic can feel his pulse racing now that he has you here with him. The excitement of the fight to come, the eagerness to see the look on Saitama’s face when he sees that Sonic is holding his cute, little friend hostage.

Bringing his face closer to yours, his heart does something weird. It’s like a brief acceleration, making his pulse skip. Maybe it’s the way you’re blushing or maybe it’s just that he hasn’t seen your face up close like this before. His hand leaves the top of your head and grips your jaw, holding you still so he can study you.

There’s something undeniably cute about you. A little fire in your eyes, an endearing sort of pout when you try to look away and find his fingers gripping tighter. Sonic can feel this weird tingle where his fingers touch you and it’s spreading through him. Oh…that’s not good.

It’s bad because he likes the way it makes him feel. So much so that he can feel his grin spreading. Unprofessionally wide, wild, and he can’t seem to get rid of it. Even when he sees your eyes widen, it doesn’t do anything to affect his grin.

Staring back at him, still kind of confused about him calling you Saitama’s weakness, your eyes are focused on his grin. It’s unlike anything you’ve ever seen before and somewhere at the back of your mind, you know you should be freaked out. It’s just that…it’s kind of cute. Maybe it’s because he looks so excited.

“H-how am I his weakness?” It doesn’t make sense to you. Sure, you hang out with Saitama sometimes, but it’s not like you’re super close.

“He won’t be able to resist the urge to save you,” he answers, his delight leaking into his voice. “I left a challenge on his door and told him where to meet me tomorrow. He won’t be able to ignore my challenge because I have you. He won’t risk his friend’s safety by brushing me aside. And if I have you there at the fight, I can keep using you to my advantage.”

Before you can try to argue or even explain that his plan might not work, you feel his warm fingertips stroke along your jaw. It sends a pleasant shiver down your spine and your eyes half-close. Your teeth sink into the inside of your cheek to keep yourself quiet as you drag your gaze away from those large, grey eyes.

The back of your head is still throbbing from getting smacked against the street earlier, making tears swell at the corners of your eyes. You finally have to close them, clenching your jaw and vaguely wondering if you might have a concussion. His fingers leave your skin and you hear a rattling sound before something cold is pressed against your cheek.

“Here. Take these.” Sonic meets your gaze when your eyes open, giving you an expectant look. In one hand, he’s holding a bottle of painkillers and in the other, he’s holding a bottle of water to the side of your face.

You stare back at him for a moment, wondering if he remembers that your wrists are bound behind your back. Giving a tug at your restraints, you look over your shoulder at the tight binding and then turn your eyes to Sonic again. “I can’t?”

“What?” He leans forward again with an air of intimidation…until he remembers. Without offering an apology, he just opens the bottle and lifts two painkillers to your lips, pushing against the plush flesh. “Open.”

It’s so soft. There’s warmth rising to his face as he slips the pills and his fingertips past your lips and into your mouth. He manages to contain his excitement to a half-grin as his fingers brush against your tongue and bottom lip. Soon they’re pulled away and he opens the water bottle.

Your face feels hot as you sip the cold water and swallow the painkillers. He’s still sitting really close to you and now you’re even more flustered than before. “…thanks…” you mumble, turning your head to the side.

Sonic doesn’t say anything. Instead, he stands and carries the bottles into the small kitchen area. Something feels “off”. Why aren’t you scared? It’s not like he’s planning to actually hurt you, but you don’t have any way of knowing that.

For all you know, he could be planning to slit your throat the second you fall asleep again. He might be planning to torture you and cut off little bits and pieces to send Saitama if he doesn’t show up for the fight. So how and why are you staying so calm?

He grimaces and hears the quiet creak of the rope around your wrists. You’re trying to escape, you want to escape, so it’s not like you’ve just given up hope. Maybe you think you’re strong enough to take him on by yourself. You did manage to get a jab in with that stun gun earlier.

The ninja is standing with his back to you, his head lowered and loose, dark hair falling around his face. A wide grin splits his face and he covers his mouth as he glances back at you again. Take him on? Someone like you? You’re probably a Class B hero, at best, right? And you think you can stop a professional killer like-?

“Sonic-san. I need to use the bathroom,” you interrupt.

“Seriously?” Turning to face you again, he sees you squirming a bit and knows he should probably allow it.

As soon as you’re in the bathroom with the door closed, you finally let the panic wash over you. Subconsciously keeping it at bay since you woke up, you can now feel your heart hammering in your chest. What the hell have you gotten yourself into? This man kidnapped you to use as bait for Saitama, but you’ve got a gut feeling that it’s not going to work.

Didn’t Sonic say that Saitama won’t be able to ignore him this time? Or something along those lines. That makes it seem like Saitama has been actively avoiding fighting him! And you know the bald hero well enough by now to know he won’t do anything he doesn’t want to do! What if he doesn’t show up for the fight?!

Calm down, calm down. You pace a little in this tiny room, staring down at your hands. Sonic untied you and then bound your wrists in front of you so you can take care of yourself in the bathroom. There are some faint red marks around your wrists and you know you’re probably going to have bruises once you’re released.

So! No phone, no stun gun, limited use of your hands. How are you going to get away? Your eyes dart around the bathroom, but there’s nothing in here to help you escape. Just some soaps and shampoo, toothbrush, stray hairbands, and…the mirror above the sink.

You pause and look at your reflection, perplexed. Didn’t you scrape your face on the road earlier? You had blood running down your face when he attacked you. Now, you can see that some bandages have been plastered over your injuries and it looks like he cleaned away all of the dried blood. If you’re just a hostage and he wants Saitama to feel like you need protected, why did he bother cleaning you up?

“Don’t keep me waiting,” he warns from the other side of the door. The wood creaks as he leans against it and you can imagine the smirk on his lips.

“Sorry! Just a second.” Why did you apologize? You shake your head as you run the sink water. There’s no way you can try to escape while he’s awake. He was so much faster than you when he attacked you earlier. Your best chance is to wait until he falls asleep and then try to slip out of here.

Sonic isn’t stupid. He knows what you’re thinking when you sit across from him on the floor to eat dinner. You’re going to wait for him to fall asleep and then try to escape. He wouldn’t expect less from someone like you. It’s too bad that he’s so well trained; he just won’t fall asleep before you do.

Instead of the evening ending with a fight or with you triumphantly fleeing his base, you fall asleep around the same time he does. You, leaning against Sonic’s side with your back against the wall. Sonic, beside you with his arm wrapped around you shoulders in a half-hearted attempt at keeping you upright. The night ends with you both slumping over onto the floor with you cuddling up against him.

The next morning, Saitama steps out of his apartment and has to pause when he sees the weird note that’s stuck to the door. Reading it makes him raise an eyebrow and call out to Genos, who’s in the middle of cleaning the kitchen. “Hey. Who’s Y/N?”

Sonic’s plan had overlooked one crucial detail. Saitama doesn’t know your real name. Since the day you met, he’s called you “Delivery-chan” or “delivery girl”. He never uses your real name, despite the fact that you wear a name badge. Truthfully, he only knows you by the nicknames he’s given you.

So, sadly, this ransom note from Sonic saying that he has “Y/N” doesn’t really mean anything to Saitama. He shrugs it off and shoves the note into his pocket before he sets off again. It only dawns on him that “Y/N” might be you when he finds your bike sitting abandoned in the street with a shuriken buried in the back tire.

As your sweet dream of lounging in your own apartment begins to recede, reality smacks you in the face. You can feel the cold, hard floor against your side, but opening your eyes shows that you’re not alone. Sonic’s face is just a short distance away from yours and you can hear his heart beating beneath your ear, feel the rise and fall of his chest.

Heat rushes to your face as your fingers curl, gripping at his shirt from where your bound hands are pressed against his side. Every muscle tenses as you look up at his face. His eyes are closed, lips just barely parted, and it’s pretty clear he’s genuinely asleep.

Speed o’ Sound Sonic. That’s what he said his name was, right? He’s obviously not a hero since he kidnapped you, but that’s a really unusual name. The way he was acting yesterday, it kind of seems like he sees Saitama as a rival. So what exactly is he?

Cute. The thought makes you quickly look away and your hands curl into fists, the rope biting deeper into your wrists. Closing your eyes, you try to push that thought away and calm your racing pulse.

He’s asleep right now! This could be your only chance to escape! The problem is that you don’t know where he put your cellphone and stun gun. You don’t even know where his “base” is so you might be really far away from your apartment.

Very, very carefully, you try to draw away from him. Lifting your head off his chest and shuffling backwards a little. Your stomach clenches with anxiety as you stare at his face, watching for any sign that he’s waking up. His eyelids stay closed, but his mouth begins to twitch slightly so you freeze.

Seconds tick by as you watch and wait. Staying absolutely still until he finally seems to sink back into a deep sleep. Just a bit more and you can turn onto your back. Then you’ll be able to push yourself up and…

You almost yelp when you feel Sonic’s arm wrap around your waist and drag you back to him. Your teeth close on your bottom lip to muffle it to a quiet squeak. Your heart is beating out of control as you find your face pressed into his chest. Both of his arms slide around you, his body pressing against yours, but he’s still silent.

Is he awake? You manage to draw your face back a little and lift your gaze. From what you can see, he’s still asleep. Completely unaware of how he’s cuddling against you on the floor. Totally oblivious to the very unfortunate position of your bound wrists being trapped between your body and his, your hands against his crotch.

When is he going to wake up? What’s going to happen when he wakes up? You close your eyes tightly and try to keep your breathing steady, but it’s hard to stay calm in a situation like this.

You’re not sure how much time passes. Lying there with his arms wrapped around you, trying to stay still, feeling him move in his sleep to get more comfortable. It feels like your face is burning when his hips press forward, rubbing himself against your hands and burying his face in your hair.

When he finally stirs awake, you’re surprised that he simply releases you. Sonic pushes himself to sit up, stray locks of dark hair falling over his eyes, and grimaces when he checks the time on his phone. You struggle to push yourself up as well while he makes his way to the kitchen.

“We don’t have a lot of time before my fight. You’ll need to eat fast.” He rummages in the fridge for something and pulls out a convenience store rice ball, still in its packaging. “Eat this while I get ready.”

You manage to catch it when he tosses it your way, but you’re still really confused. He’s acting like nothing happened. Maybe he doesn’t care? Why does that…make you feel a little disappointed? Why should it matter if this weirdo that you just met yesterday cares about cuddling with you?

“Why?” Lifting a hand, he rubs at the back of his neck and tilts his head a little. “I don’t know. It can be kind of risky to confess your feelings, right? What if she doesn’t feel the same way you do? It might make her uncomfortable if you confess and she doesn’t like you back. I guess it is Delivery-chan so she might still be okay with…”

Sighing, he turns his body to face the cyborg. “Genos, you’re going to tell her anyway, aren’t you? Let’s practice. Come here.”

Genos casts a glance back to where you’re asleep before leaving your side to sit closer to Saitama. Facing his mentor, he nods. “Alright. I will pretend that I am telling Delivery-chan my feelings.”

“That’s right. Just pretend that I’m her and tell me how you feel.” The bald hero rests an elbow on the table and gives him a nod. “Just be direct.”

“Yes.” For a moment, the cyborg sits staring intensely back at Saitama. Unblinking, completely focused, as if he’s calculating the best way to convey his feelings for you. Finally, after a full minute, he speaks again. “Delivery-chan, I have developed inappropriate feelings for you.”

In an instant, Saitama’s expression shifts from his usual deadpan face to something much more serious. Leaning forward, he rests a hand on his student’s shoulder. “Genos, no. Do you want to go to jail?”

“Master? I was only stating my feelings-”

“Just don’t say it that way. You’re going to sound creepy. Never say that again.”

“Please coach me. My experience with confessing feelings is limited, but I can tell that you have much more experience in this area.” Leaning closer, Genos is almost tempted to take notes. He’s sure that Saitama has a lot of experience with romance and not just due to his age. Surely someone as powerful as his mentor has been approached by countless women and of course he’s probably confessed his feelings plenty of times. Genos is sure that he hasn’t been turned down.

“Oh. Yeah, uh, sure.” Saitama is trying not to let it show that he, in fact, does not have experience in that field. He can’t remember the last time he actually had a crush on someone, let alone the last time he confessed to someone.

You have the misfortune of waking up across the room from them both just as Saitama is telling Genos to not stare. With your eyes focused on the ceiling, you can’t see them, but you can hear them. The way the older hero is spouting some dating advice that sounds like the sagely sort of advice you’d read in a shoujo manga. It’s tempting to just sit up and excuse yourself to leave, but if you do that, you’ll draw attention to yourself.

If you let Genos know that you’re awake, he’s going to launch into a lecture. You know that you should’ve been more careful when you were fighting those monsters, but it was your first time intentionally fighting them. It was your first time using those swords that he gifted you.

You can feel pressure against your cheek, where he taped a gauze pad over your cuts. There’s another pressure against your thigh, another bandage covering the deep wound there. Moving just a little beneath the blanket, your pulse quickens when you realize that the bandage is between your skin and the blanket with no barrier in between.

Darting your eyes to the side, you hope to spot your pants and hoodie sitting off to the side. Your pulse accelerates further when you don’t see them there. The sight of them hanging up outside makes your stomach clench and you chew at the inside of your cheek.

It’s an awkward situation, to be lying there without pants with two guys talking romance a short distance away. The second that you sit up, they’re going to look over. Even though you have a blanket covering you, this still feels weird. You know you can’t just stay there, though.

Pushing yourself to sit up, you tuck the blanket around your waist to keep your lower half covered. Though the fact that your wound was bandaged tells you that someone’s already seen your legs, someone’s already seen your panties, and you’re pretty sure it wasn’t Saitama. Your eyes fall briefly on Genos before lowering as they both turn their heads to look your way.

“Oh, cool. You’re awake. Feeling okay?” Saitama tilts his head, leaning a bit to the side so he can look at you directly.

“Uh…yeah. I’m okay. I just got a little banged up.” You’re not sure what to do now. Neither of them are making a move to get your pants and hoodie from the porch. You start to contemplate getting them yourself and just keeping the blanket wrapped around your waist, but Genos interrupts your thoughts.

“Delivery-chan, I have something important that I need to tell you.” Leaving the table, he approaches where you’re sitting on the floor.

You’re sure that he’s going to lecture you about the way you handled those monsters. He’s going to go on a rant about how careless you were, how a real hero never would have let themselves get as injured as you did. Anticipating the cyborg’s lecture, you lower your head.

“I have recently discovered that I have feelings for you that go beyond what a teacher should feel for their student. I’m not sure when it began, but I have recently realized that these feelings towards you are romantic. Before you lost consciousness, I confessed to you that I have strange feelings for you, but I’m not sure if you remember, so I wanted to tell you again.”

The blond cyborg leans closer and plants a hand on your shoulder. “Delivery-chan. I am going to say this as directly as possible, just as my master advised. I have a crush on you and I would like for you to return my feelings. I want to begin a romantic relationship with you and I understand that you might not feel the same way, but like Master Saitama told me a few minutes ago that “you miss 100% of the chances you don’t take”. I believe that we should attempt a date so that both of us can be sure of our feelings and if you do feel the same way towards me, then we can make our relationship official.”

You stare back at him, unsure of what to say. It really felt like he hated you. Complaining about you to the delivery company, throwing a fit when his orders didn’t have enough sauce or the restaurant forgot the disposable chopsticks or napkins, filming you so he could claim that you were late with the deliveries, and then the general sassiness that he always had when he talked to you. Looking back on it now, you almost wonder if it’s like how little boys pick on the girls they like to try to get their attention.

“You have…a crush on me?” Saying it only deepens your confusion. Before you became his student, you were just the delivery girl. You had limited interaction. “What do you like about me?”

Both you and Saitama expect him to pause for a moment and consider the question, but apparently Genos already had a mental list of everything he likes about you. He likes your determination and speed, he likes your dedication to becoming stronger, he likes the fact that you’re so willing to learn whatever he can teach you. Of course, there are more things that he likes as well. Things that take you by surprise.

Genos likes how your voice sounds first thing in the morning. The way that your armored hoodie looks on you, the color of the fabric against your skin. He hasn’t seen you smile much, but when you do smile, he thinks that it has a certain warmth to it that makes him feel…equally warm. His thoughts have started to get a little fuzzy when he sees your smile or even thinks about it. Your thoughtfulness, your kindness, those softer things are what he goes deeper into detail about with no shred of embarrassment.

“So? What do you think, Delivery-chan?” Saitama nudges your elbow and raises an eyebrow, his expression ever so slightly smug.

If Sonic finds out about this, you just know that he’s going to try to fight Genos. You can already picture the fight and imagine him getting effortlessly hurled halfway across City Z with a hit from Saitama. Chewing at the inside of your cheek, you lower your eyes to the floor and try to think of what to say.

“When you visit tomorrow, I would like for us to try a different activity. We will still train, but that will only be for a few hours. Please bring a change of clothes with you tomorrow.” Genos leaves the table and you can hear him walk to the kitchen.

With that over, you look towards the porch in the hopes of retrieving your pants and hoodie. Before you can even consider getting up, Genos is back and setting a bowl of food in front of you. A can of juice is set down beside it and he wordlessly sits beside you to begin eating his own meal.

“Hey. Since you’re done training for the day, want to help me train in this game I borrowed?” Saitama tilts his head when you look his way. “You didn’t have anything else to do, right? Oh! By the way…”

Turning, he retrieved the little black kitten from his futon and settled it onto your lap. “There you go. Nara was pretty worried about you, Delivery-chan.”

“Nara?” Looking down at the kitten, you see it curling up and dozing off again.

“Yeah. I came up with the name while you were training. It’s pretty cool, right?”
